message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible erectile dysfunction which can be caused by either organic or psychogenic factors. Penile tumescence testing is specifically intended to distinguish between the two causes. Biothesiometry measures the vibration sensation in the penis and is used to diagnose peripheral neuropathy. Injection of prostaglandin E1 and angiography are invasive tests used to evaluate erectile dysfunction in specific cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the possibility of both organic (such as diabetes) and psychogenic causes of his condition. Penile tumescence testing is specifically intended to distinguish between these causes by measuring nighttime erections. Organic causes can still result in nighttime erections, while psychogenic causes typically do not. Biothesiometry and injection of prostaglandin E1 are used to evaluate for erectile dysfunction, but do not distinguish between the causes. Angiography is not typically used for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Penile tumescence testing is the specific test that distinguishes between the organic and psychogenic cause of the patient’s condition. It involves monitoring penile erections during sleep to determine if there is a physical cause for the erectile dysfunction. Biothesiometry, injection of prostaglandin E1, and angiography are all tests used to diagnose organic causes of erectile dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest both organic and psychogenic causes. Penile tumescence testing is used to distinguish between the organic and psychogenic causes of erectile dysfunction. Biothesiometry is used to measure the vibration perception threshold of the penis, while injection of prostaglandin E1 and angiography are used to assess blood flow to the penis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest erectile dysfunction, which may be caused by organic or psychogenic factors. Penile tumescence testing can help distinguish between organic and psychogenic factors by measuring the patient’s nocturnal erections. Biothesiometry measures the vibratory sensation in the penis and can distinguish between neuropathic and non-neuropathic causes. Injection of prostaglandin E1 and angiography can help diagnose vascular causes of erectile dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including decreased libido and inability to achieve an erection along with depressed mood, suggest that the underlying cause could be either organic or psychogenic. Penile tumescence testing is specifically intended to distinguish between the two. Biothesiometry measures sensitivity and cannot differentiate between organic and psychogenic causes. Injection of prostaglandin E1 and angiography are not used for differentiating between organic and psychogenic causes but rather to identify the cause of erectile dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the possibility of both organic and psychogenic causes for his condition, and penile tumescence testing is commonly used to help distinguish between the two. Biothesiometry measures the sensitivity of the penis to vibration and is used to evaluate nerve function in men with erectile dysfunction. Injection of prostaglandin E1 and angiography are invasive tests and are not typically used as a first-line diagnostic tool for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Penile tumescence testing is specifically used to distinguish between organic and psychogenic causes of erectile dysfunction. Biothesiometry and injection of prostaglandin E1 are used to assess penile sensitivity and vascular response, respectively. Angiography is an invasive imaging test that is not typically used for the initial evaluation of erectile dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, and depressed mood that may be caused by psychological or organic factors. Penile tumescence testing can help distinguish between these factors by measuring the number, duration, and rigidity of nocturnal erections. Biothesiometry is not specific to distinguish between organic and psychogenic causes, and injection of prostaglandin E1 and angiography are not typically used for this purpose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Penile tumescence testing can distinguish between an organic and psychogenic cause of the patient’s condition. Biothesiometry, injection of prostaglandin E1, and angiography are not used for this purpose.
